review_blob: Bottle 650ml. Poured golden with a slight haze and a good sized, frothy, off-white head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of resinous fruity hops with caramel malts, toffee, passionfruit, apricots and zesty orange marmalade. Flavor was a moderate fruity hop bitterness with biscuity malts, caramel, peaches, dry nectarines, grapefruit, hints of nuts and a dry hoppy finish. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, slightly chewy texture and a good length finish.

Bottle 355ml. Poured hazy dark burnt bronze with a small, frothy, tanned head which was fully diminishing. A complex and rich aroma with fruitcake dunked in brandy, caramelized dates, figs, sultanas, dried apricots, dark chocolate and allspice. Flavor was quite smooth with a mild bitterness, sticky toffee malts, dried mixed fruits, dark chocolate, caramelized dates, currents, muscatels, pepper, allspice and light notes of powdered ginger. Noticeable alcohol content. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, a syrupy texture and a great length finish.
beer_name: Flying Dog Horn Dog Barley Wine

review_blob: Bottle 375ml. Aged 18 months piror to tasting. Poured cloudy golden with a large, foamy, off-white head which was mostly lasting. Strong notes of funky wild yeast in the aroma with barnyard notes, forest floor notes, wet grain, lemon juice, lemon zest and vitamin C. Flavor was of acidic fruit with sour grain, wild yeast, moss, barnyard notes, petrified wood, tart green grape skins and cumquats. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry/tart mouthfeel and a good length finish.

Bottle 375ml. Aged 18 months piror to tasting. Poured hazy bloody pink with an averaged sized, pink, frothy head which was mostly diminishing. Aroma was of acidic fruit with strong notes of musty wild yeast, sea water, cranberry juice, sour raspberries and fresh lemon juice. A very strong acidity in the flavor with sour yeasty notes, tart acidic fruit, sour cherries, fresh lemon juice, unripe cranberries, salty/brine-like notes and light notes of white-whine vinegar. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry/tart mouthfeel, slightly syrupy texture and a long length finish.

Bottle 375ml. Aged 18 months piror to tasting. Poured dark muddy blood with a small, pink, frothy head which was mostly lasting. Aroma had almost perfume like characteristics with notes of roses, violets, crushed raspberries, sour cherries, wild yeast and salt water. Flavor was extremely tart with a massive acidic bite; gooseberry skins, sour cherries, red wine vinegar and light notes of oysters & salty brine. Medium bodied with lively carbonation, a dry/spritzig mouthfeel, ever-so slightly syrupy texture and a superb length finish. Amazingly delicate yet infinitely complex.

Bottle 750ml swing-top. Poured hazy golden orange with an averaged sized, sticky foamy, off-white head which was most lasting. A fruity hop aroma with floral notes; sweet biscuity malts, caramel, overripe kiwifruit, canned pineapple and peaches. Flavor was a good spicy hop bitterness with sweet biscuity malts, caramel, hop resins, white pepper, kiwifruit, passionfruit, overripe nectarines and a dry grassy finish. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, slick texture and a long length finish. Extremely well balanced, very moreish  almost seasonable.

Bottle 330ml. Poured hazy burnt copper with an averaged sized, frothy, lightly tanned head which lasted well. Aroma was of toffee malts with light notes of earthy hops, caramel, nuts, Anzac biscuits, overripe peaches and sultanas. Flavor was smooth with a light earthy hop bitterness, slightly buttery toffee malts, caramel, red berries and ripe nectarines and a nutty finish. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, watery texture and a decent length finish. Seemed more an ESB than it did an Irish Red IMO.

Bottle 355ml. Poured dark ruby brown (almost black) with a good sized, dense, foamy, lightly tanned head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of roasted malts with dark chocolate, toast, coffee, raisins and some nuts. Flavor was a medium earthy hop bitterness with roasted malts, bitter chocolate, toast, black coffee, currents, light notes of plum and a dry finish. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation, a dry toasty mouthfeel and a decent length finish.

Bottle 355ml. Poured golden orange with a slight haze and a dense, frothy, white head which was mostly diminishing. Aroma was of orange zest with floral hops, mandarin, lime juice, yeasty notes and hints of fennel seeds. Flavor was an extremely light bitterness with bready malts, oranges, lemon zest, dried pears, cinnamon, light notes of wild yeasty and a touch of grain in the finish. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation, a creamy mouthfeel, watery texture and an average length finish.
beer_name: Flying Dog Garde Dog Bire de Garde

review_blob: Bottle 355ml. Poured muddy straw with an averaged sized, fizzy, off-white head which was fully diminishing. A yeasty aroma with bready malts, bubblegum, ripe banana, cloves, vanilla and light notes of hay. Flavor had virtually no bitterness with sweet yeasty malts, banana sweets, creamy ripe pears, cinnamon, cloves and straw. Light bodied with medium carbonation, a watery texture, creamy mouthfeel and a short length finish.

Bottle 355ml. Poured hazy amber with a good sized, sticky, off-white head which lasted very well. A fruity hop aroma with caramel malts, overripe nectarines, orange citrus, passionfruit and canned pineapple rings. Flavor was a mild fruity hop bitterness with dry biscuity malts, caramel, passionfruit, grapefruit, apricots and a dry finish. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, watery texture and a good length finish.

Bottle 330ml. Poured dark, burnt, hazy bronze with a large, frothy, off-white head which lasted well. Aroma was of allspice with cinnamon, pepper, wood, dried apricots, sweet caramelized figs, toffee and light notes of yeast. Flavor was extremely light despite alcohol content with an almost non-existent bitterness, hints of spices, toffee, light notes of caramelized dates, light notes of blueberries, light notes of almond flakes, some woody notes and black pepper in the finish. Amazingly well hidden alcohol content seemed closer to 5.5%-6%. Light to medium bodied with light carbonation, a thin texture and an average length finish. I was extremely disappointed with this one, just seemed far to thin IMO  the Wicked Elf Pale ale even has more body than this! Also seems really pointless to cellar as I would imagine the flavor would die out more rather than develop  that being said its drinkable all the same, just wouldnt re-visit it anytime soon.

Bottle 330ml. Poured extremely dark brown (virtually black) with a large, dense, frothy (virtually creamy), lightly tanned head which lasted extremely well. Aroma was of toasted malts with notes of dark chocolate, coffee, a touch of liquorice and hints of blueberries & blackberries. Flavor was smooth with a mild earthy hop bitterness, roasted malts, toast, lactic/sour milk notes (pleasant), nuts and light notes of ash in the finish. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, watery texture and a decent length finish. Cant help but think this is very similar to the regular Guinness (with the exception of the slightly increased alcohol content and no widget in the bottle).

Bottle 330ml 5.5%. Poured muddy golden orange with a large, white, creamy head which lasted amazingly. Strong notes of clove and ripe bananas in the aroma with notes of sweet yeasty malts, lemon zest, orange citrus and light notes of ginger. Flavor was very smooth with a very mild bitterness, creamy vanilla, sweet sour dough, dried banana, ripe pears, cloves, cinnamon and a crisp/dry finish. Light to medium bodied with lively carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, watery texture and a good length finish.

Bottle 370ml. Poured dark ruby with an averaged sized, dense, frothy, beige head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was dominated by instant coffee and coco powder with toasted malts, dusty carob chocolate, caramel, currents, earthy/woody notes and hints of nuts. Flavor was a light earthy hop bitterness with roasted malts, toast, coco powder, chocolate coated coffee beans, carob chocolate and a dry finish. Well hidden alcohol content. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry toasty mouthfeel and a good length finish.

Bottle 750ml Swing-top. Poured black with a good sized, frothy, light brown head which lasted well. Strong notes of fruity hops in the aroma with notes of grapefruit, pineapple, overripe peaches, hop resins, caramel malts, light notes of chocolate and hints of earthy leather. Flavor was a good tropical hop bitterness with toffee malts, caramel, passionfruit, pineapple rings in syrup, overripe nectarines, light roasted notes, touch of chocolate and hop resins in the finish. Very well hidden alcohol content. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation, a dry/hoppy mouthfeel, somewhat syrupy texture and a long finish. This one seemed a little everywhere IMO  seemed like the result of pouring half a bottle of Imperial IPA into half a bottle of a good quality Foreign Stout.

Bottle 355ml. Poured extremely dark brown with a small, frothy, light brown head which lasted very well. A complex aroma with sticky toffee malts, rum & raisin chocolate, dusty chocolate mud cake, caramelized dates, currents, muscatels, dried apricots, dried pineapple, and fruity hop resins. Flavor was simply remarkable and quite smooth despite the high IBUs with notes of sticky toffee malts, rum & raisin chocolate, rich fruit cake with caramel sauce, currents, blueberries and great hoppy notes which compliment the flavor rather than conflict. Full bodied with soft carbonation, a syrupy texture and a long lightly warming finish.
beer_name: Left Hand Wake Up Dead Imperial Stout

review_blob: Bottle 750ml. Aged for 2 years piror to tasting. Poured golden straw with a slight haze and a large, frothy, off-white head which was mostly diminishing. Aroma was of floral hops with sweet yeasty malts, lemon citrus, mandarin, apricots, cinnamon, coriander, hay and light barnyard notes. Flavor was a mild spicy hop bitterness with bready malts, tangy lemon zest, orange peel, green grapes, coriander and light notes of white pepper. Medium bodied with mild carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, slick texture and a long length finish.

Bottle 750ml. Aged 9 months piror to tasting. Poured dark brown with a large, tight, foamy, lightly tanned head which was fully lasting.  A complex aroma with notes of sweet milk chocolate, coco powder, yeasty malts, plums, blueberries, dried apricots, allspice, light notes of coffee and a dash of brandy. Flavor was smooth with virtually no bitterness, yeasty malts, chocolate, prunes, blackberries, sultanas and a touch of vanilla & cinnamon. Very well masked alcohol content. Medium bodied with soft carbonation, a somewhat syrupy texture and a good length finish.

Bottle 750ml. Aged 6 months piror to tasting. Poured dark brown (virtually black) with a tinge of red and a large, dense, frothy, lightly tanned head which was fully lasting. A very strong and complex aroma with dark chocolate, rasins, blueberries, dates, figs, caramel, pepper, allspice and spiced gingerbread. Flavor was a light bitterness with rum & raisin chocolate, currents, blackberries, plums, roasted notes, ginger powder, hints of caramelized figs, a touch of coffee and a warming finish. Remarkably well balanced; beautiful contrast in flavours. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, a lightly syrupy texture and a long length finish.

Bottle 500 ml. Poured gold with a small, rocky, off-white head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of earthy/fruity hops with orange citrus, zesty lemon citrus, biscuity malts, caramel, apricots and light notes of passionfruit. Flavor was a mild earthy/fruity hop bitterness with notes of ripe nectarines, passionfruit, biscuity malts, toffee, light notes of hop resins and a dry finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation, a dry/hoppy mouthfeel and a good length finish. Drinks well above its ABV.

Bottle 500 ml. Poured cloudy burnt copper with a large, off-white, rocky head which was mostly lasting. A woody aroma with notes of white pepper, toffee malts, nuts, caramelized dried mixed fruits, dried apricots and hints of spiced cookies. Flavor was a light earthy hop bitterness with toffee malts, all spice, pepper, overripe peaches & apricots, caramel, wood and a spicy/warming finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation, an almost chewy mouthfeel and a good length finish.
Bottle 370 ml 3.5%. Age roughly 1 year piror to tasting. Poured deep dark ruby with an averaged sized, loose, rocky, purple head which was mostly diminishing. Aroma was of Ribena &#

Bottle 370 ml. Age roughly 1 year piror to tasting. Poured cloudy deep ruby with dark purple highlights and a good sized, rocky, violet coloured head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of fruit acids with freshly crushed raspberries, cranberry juice, lemon juice and light musty/yeasty notes. Flavor was also of tart fruit acids with tart raspberries, sour cherries, light notes of lemon juice, musty/yeast notes and a dry crisp finish. Light bodied with lively carbonation, a dry/tart mouthfeel, lightly syrupy texture and a good length finish. Very well balanced and unbelievably refreshing.

Bottle 500ml 4.1%. Poured very dark brown (virtually black) with a small, off-white, frothy head which lasted well. Aroma was of roasted malts with toast, black coffee, toasted nuts, liquorice and light notes of raisins. Flavor was a light earthy bitterness with roasted malts, sweet milk chocolate, light lactic/sour milk notes, a touch of caramel and a dry toasty/nutty finish. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, watery texture and a good length finish.

Can 440ml 3.5%. Poured golden orange with an averaged sized, creamy, yellowed head which lasted very well. Aroma was of sweet bread with honey oat cereal, sweet caramel malts, nuts and hints of peaches. Flavor was of sweet bread with an almost non existent earthy bitterness, caramel malts, honey, some wet straw, hints of pear and a dry nutty finish. Light bodied with soft carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, watery texture and a short length finish. Reasonably sessionable bitter IMO  I wish Australia could brew mid strengths even half this tasty.

Bottle (500ml). Poured cloudy burnt copper with a good sized, dense, foamy, off-white head which lasted very well. Aroma was of earthy hops with caramel malts, nectarines, ripe peaches, canned pears and grassy notes. Flavor was a medium earthy hop bitterness with toffee malts, dry apricots, overripe nectarines, dried apples and notes of earthy hop resin in the finish. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, watery texture and a decent length finish.

Bottle (500ml). Poured black with a good sized dense, tanned, frothy head which lasted very well. A complex aroma with notes of treacle, roasted malts, toast, smoke, coffee beans, Belgian truffles, raisins and fleshly ground black pepper. Flavor was of toasted malts with a good level of bitterness, lactic/sour milk notes, bitter black coffee, large notes of black pepper, homemade liquorice, molasses, dark rum & raisin chocolate, currents, pleasant earthy notes and a superb dry finish. Noticeable alcohol content. Very full bodied with soft carbonation, an oily texture, thick/ chewy mouthfeel and a long finish. A truly remarkable Imperial Stout.

Bottle (330ml). Age roughly 1 year piror to tasting. Poured dark burnt bronze with a good sized, lightly tanned, dense foamy head which was mostly lasting. A complex aroma with notes of citric acid, dried apricots, dates, port, cinnamon, allspice, wood, light notes of rum & raisin chocolate and a touch of caramel in the back. Flavor was of tart fruit acids with sour cherries & raspberries, tart lemon, balsamic vinegar, salt, allspice, light note of fermenting plums and hints of wood in the finish. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry/tart mouthfeel, slick texture and a good length finish.

Bottle (750ml). Age roughly 1 year piror to tasting. Poured muddy golden brown with extremely large chunks of yeast (some of the biggest I have seen to date) and a large frothy, white head which lasted superbly. A complex and intriguing aroma with white pepper,  fermenting pears, granny smith apples, lemon citrus, herbaceous hops, sweet sour dough, sawdust, barnyard hay, lavender and coriander. Strong notes of freshly cracked black pepper in the flavor with coriander, sweet bready malts, light bitterness, lemon zest, dry pears, straw and a lightly warming finish. Full bodied with medium bodied with a spicy/hot mouthfeel, a moderately thick texture and a relatively short finish. Being a fan of big beers, particularly ones with strong notes of alcohol this beer worked well for me.

Bottle (330ml). Poured muddy dark copper with a good sized frothy, beige head which lasted extremely well. Spicy, complex aroma with notes of wild yeast with freshly baked cinnamon bread, honey oats, allspice, caramelized dates, boiled sweets and preserved apricots. Flavor was incredible, with strong notes of black pepper with sweet wholegrain bread, almond flakes, dried mixed fruits, fermenting peaches, cinnamon with a warming superb finish. Full bodied with medium carbonation, a warming mouthfeel, and a fantastic length finish.

Bottle (650ml). Poured extremely dark brown (virtually black) with a dense, tanned, frothy head which lasted well. Aroma was of tropical hops with pineapple rings, ripe apricots, roasted hazelnuts, new leather and hints of carob chocolate. Flavor was somewhat similar to aroma with a moderate tropical hop bitterness with nectarines, caramel malts, toast, black coffee and a dry earthy finish with some light hop resins. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, slick texture and a great length finish.

Nitro-can (440ml). Poured copper coloured with a thick creamy, off-white head which lasted superbly. A light aroma with notes of sweet bread, caramel malts, biscuits and red berries. Flavor was a very light earthy bitterness with caramel malts, gooseberries and some nuts. Light bodied with virtually no carbonation, a watery texture, creamy mouthfeel and a short lived, clean finish.

Bottle (355ml). Aged roughly 9 months piror to tasting. Poured inky black with a medium sized dense, frothy (almost creamy) tanned head which lasted very well. A complex and rich aroma with strong notes of burnt sugar and sticky toffee, toasted malts, milk chocolate, caramelized dates, fruitcake dunked in brandy, smoke and honey roasted nuts. Flavor was a fantastic lactic/sour bitterness with notes of new leather, roasted malts, toast, bitter chocolate, black coffee, smoke, toasted nuts and a dry earthy finish. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, an oily texture, very dry mouthfeel and a superb finish.

Bottle (500). Poured hazy burnt ruby with a huge lightly tanned, creamy head which lasted superbly. Aroma was of earthy hops with orange peel, toffee malts, red berries, 5 spice, caramel and hints of fennel. Flavor was a good rustic/earthy hop bitterness with toffee malts, juicy gooseberries, figs, black pepper and a very dry woody finish. Noticeable alcohol content. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, a dry mouthfeel and a superb length finish. Very well crafted English Strong Ale from Fullers  perfect full-bodied winter warmer.

Bottle (750ml) Aged roughly 9 months piror to tasting. Poured muddy burnt brown with a small, dense, frothy, lightly tanned head which lasted very well. Aroma was of spiced cookies with cinnamon, allspice, nutmeg, pepper, plums, figs, blueberries and rum & raisin chocolate. Flavor was of yeasty malts with a light bitterness, strong notes of tart blueberries, dates, currents, caramel, chocolate, brown sugar, cinnamon and a slightly acidic finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation, an oily texture and a good length finish.
UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009

Bottle (750ml). Aged roughly 1 year piror to tasting. Poured an extremely burnt copper with a good sized, dense frothy, lightly tanned head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of wholegrain bread with floral hops, dried pineapple, lemon citrus, guava, pears, dates, caramel, straw and some cinnamon. Flavor was a tangy hop bitterness with lemon citrus, passionfruit, dry pears, figs, dates, toffee, white pepper, cinnamon, hay and some good woody notes in the finish. Medium bodied with lively carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, somewhat syrupy texture and a great length finish.

On tap at the Redoak. Arrived hazy burnt copper with an averaged sized, white head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of wild yeast with wholegrain bread, floral hops, orange zest, juicy gooseberries, cinnamon and hints of dried banana. Flavor was of sour yeasty malts and wild yeast with a light floral hop bitterness, straw, lemon citrus, mandarin, hints of dried pineapple and a touch of grain. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, somewhat watery texture and an average length finish. Good amount of body and flavor considering the low ABV.

Bottle (650ml). Poured black with a good sized, tanned, frothy, head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of toasted malts, with full cream milk chocolates, coco, black coffee, toast and roasted hazelnuts. Strong notes of black coffee in the flavor was a decent level of earthy hop bitterness, bitter dark chocolate, a pleasant milky/lactic/sour notes and hints of leather and nuts towards the finish. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, chewy texture and a long dry finish.

Bottle (750ml). Aged roughly 1 year piror to tasting. Poured fizzy burnt copper with a tiny, frothy, off-white head which was fully diminishing. A woody aroma with toffee malts, burnt sugar, figs, preserved plums, toffee apple sweets and hints of varnish. Flavor was a tangy acidic bitterness with sweet bready malts, strong notes of lemon citrus, zesty oranges, dry pears, crisp apples, caramelized figs and some good woody notes. Medium bodied with lively carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, thick texture and a decent length finish.

Bottle (330ml). Poured dark ruby with a good sized, lightly tanned head which was mostly lasting. A rich malty aroma with burnt sugars, toffee, dark chocolate, caramelized dates, figs and light woody notes. Flavor was a moderate earthy hop bitterness with toasted malts, roasted nuts, rich toffee, rum & raisin chocolate, muscatels, notes of wood/oak and some light notes of allspice. Very well balanced with a well masked ABV. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, a chewy mouthfeel, thick texture and a good length finish. Very rich easy drinking ale from Orkney, although it did seem much more like a Wee Heavy/Scotch Ale IMO.

Bottle (640ml). Poured copper with a good sized, dense, foamy, off-white head which lasted well. Aroma was of sweet tropical hops with pineapple, grapefruit, mango, caramel malts and some earthy notes. Flavor was a good yet shortly lived spicy hop bitterness with caramel malts, ripe peaches, ripe nectarines, pineapple rings, grapefruit, pepper, hints of toffee, light woody notes and some hop resin in the finish. Well hidden alcohol content. Medium bodied with a dry hoppy mouthfeel, syrupy texture and a short lived finish. Reminds me a lot of Flying Dogs Double Dog Double Pale Ale only with half the hops and ABV, although still very good value at $10 for 640ml. I had a second bottle which I paired with spicy beef rissoles  a true match made in haven. I think Imperial IPA is being a little generous, seemed more along the lines of an American Strong Ale or a Barley Wine IMO.

Bottle (355ml) 11.5%. Poured bronze with a good sized, sticky, off-white head which was average lasting. A intense sweet, sticky, tropical hop aroma with over ripe mangoes, over ripe peaches, grapefruit, toffee malts, caramel and some good notes of pine. Flavor was a great resiny/tropical hop bitterness with strong notes of white pepper, toffee malts, over ripe rockmelon, nectarines, pineapple rings (in syrup) and hop acids in the finish. Full bodied with medium carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, syrupy texture and a long resiny finish. Being a fan of BIG American style hoppy beers I could not get enough of this one  luckily I got my hands on a carton not a 4 pack.
beer_name: Flying Dog Double Dog Double Pale Ale

review_blob: Bottle (750ml) Cellared for 8 months. Poured golden orange with a medium sized, rocky, off-white head which was average lasting. A very strong yeasty aroma with barnyard notes, ripe pears, lemon zest, cinnamon, coriander and light notes of clove + banana. Flavor was mainly of wild yeast with a mild bitterness, over ripe apples, tangy lemon, cinnamon, pepper, coriander, hints of banana and some strange herb/weed notes which I couldnt quite put my finger on. Medium bodied with lively carbonation, a dry mouthfeel and a good length finish.

Bottle (750ml) Cellared for 8 months. Poured hazy burnt copper with a large, dense, foamy, lightly tanned head which lasted well. Aroma was of barnyard hay with green apples, sour dough, prunes, caramelized dates, allspice and light notes of powdered ginger. Flavor was a mild (pleasant) acidic bitterness with straw, caramel, dried pineapple, dry pears, figs, muscatels, allspice, white pepper and a woody finish. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a lightly acidic mouthfeel and a good length finish. Very well balanced Biere De Garde.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Bottle (330ml) Cellared for 3 years. Poured intense dark ruby with a small, frothy, lightly tanned head which was mostly diminishing. A rich, sticky, complex aroma with burnt sugar, toffee, toasted malts, dark chocolate, muscatels, prunes, caramelized dates and allspice. Flavor was of rich sticky toffee with caramelized dates, rum & raisin chocolate, fruit cake, figs, sultanas, brown sugar, light woody notes, a touch of port and a warming finish. Well hidden alcohol, very smooth with virtually no bitterness. Full bodied with very soft carbonation, a syrupy texture and a long lasting finish.

Bottle (750ml) Cellared for 6 months. Poured dark hazel with a good sized, dense foamy, lightly tanned head which was average lasting. Aroma was of funky/yeasty malts with cloves, cinnamon, plums, caramelized dates and hints of chocolate coated bananas. Flavor was mild (in terms of Dunkelweizens) with sweet yeasty malts, a light bitterness, prunes, tart blackberries, allspice, jaffa chocolates, a mild toasty note and hints of caramel. Light bodied with medium carbonation, a watery texture, thin mouthfeel and a short finish.

Bottle (750ml) Cellared for 1 year. Poured golden straw with a slight haze and a large, thick, frothy, off-white head which lasted superbly. Aroma was of sweet bread with candy sugar, apples, creamy pears, lemon zest, vanilla, cinnamon and coriander. Flavor was a moderate spicy hop bitterness with strong notes of pepper, bready malts, crisp green apples, dried pineapple, lemon citrus, cinnamon, coriander, light notes of cloves and a spicy warming finish. Medium to full bodied with lively carbonation, a dry mouthfeel, syrupy texture (mild) and a good length finish.

Bottle (750ml) Cellared for 1 year. Poured dark brown with a good sized, dense, frothy, lightly tanned head which lasted well. Aroma was of raisin bread with blackcurrant juice, muscatels, blackberries, cinnamon, pepper and some chocolate. Flavor was an extremely light bitterness with bready malts, over ripe plums, dates, sultanas, cherry chocolates, cinnamon and allspice. Alcohol content was well masked. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation, a medium texture and an average length finish
